Some ultimatum, huh? Well, I did watch it immediately.

The Big Lebowski over all was a funny film. I had more than a few good laughs. I think my favorite running gag was between John Goodman and Steve Buchemi and how John just keeps telling him to "Shut the F up, Donnie" and finally his last line to him is "These are bad men, Donnie", I'm not sure why I found it so funny, maybe it was the way it was said. It just played off so well. Also the Jesus gag, the Spanish bowlers were hilarious. Not to mention a few other scenes of The Dude getting knocked out.

But still, I'm not too sure if I found this movie to be funnier than other comedies I prefer. I think everyone has their different taste. But my sister did say to watch it one more time, so hopefully, maybe I'll get why this is such a great movie to others.

7/10

I know this will get a lot of downvotes but... this movie is not good.

I've tried. About six times now, I've seen The Big Lebowski, either most or in whole, and each time I wonder what people see in this movie.

It is was never particularly amusing, rarely eliciting even the thought of "Oh, that was funny" much less an actual chuckle. The plot isnt really engaging, as it just sort of meanders through the content. The dialogue that is often lauded, is rather weak throughout the movie, with only a few of the scenes that have been meme'd to death being some of the few "high" points. The plot... exists.

On a technical side, the sound isnt anything really praise-worthy, though I'm sure a lot of people will note the soundtrack itself, but that is addressed below.

Nor is the cinematography worth mentioning with many shots being flat/center, with an occasional dolly shot thrown in to mix things up. Even when they had a chance to make things a little more 'wild', most of the shots are still flat/center (like the Dudes bowling dream sequence).

The sound track feels almost "obvious", with certain choices feeling like they picked the most overly used choices they could find, or a close approximation.

The clothing looks good/like a bunch of Goodwill stuff bought the day before shooting, which is what they were going for sure, but the only thing that shines here is the set design.

Each locations "feels" right for its place in the story. The bowling alley is straight outta middle America, the Dudes house not only looks small, dingy, and in disrepair, but the overall choices for what went into the house clearly had a lot of thought put into it. When set design is a standout in your movie, somethings wrong. The only negative is that they made the overall space, especially the livingroom, a bit too spacious for someone like the Dude to actually have, but that is just a minor niggle.

The acting is........ fine. It is not great, or even particularly good, per se, but the actors do their jobs well. Many of the characters feel one or two dimensional at best, with others being a single trait in human form. Even the Dude himself isnt much other than a stereotype of a 'cool loser' type.

As stated, the few highs are whats already been meme'd to death, and even before that, they were more 'kooky/crazy/shocking' than actually amusing.

(For example, John Goodman pulling a gun over a bowling foul was never amusing, but the scene following it, where they are having a conversation in the car as the cops rush the place, WAS slightly amusing, but could have been done to better effect)

It does its best to get to the next scenes pretty quickly, which is a blessing in disguise, but it doesnt do even that in any particularly engaging manner either.

I know this is a big favorite amongst the 420 crowd and certain others, and by all means keep enjoying this movie.

I have tried many times to find merit in this film, even with perception altering legal substances, but its always been an extremely overrated film imho. I wish I could find what others see in this flick, but its just not there for me.

Many people have stated this as their favorite movie. I've heard many different angles on why people enjoy it, but I still do not see what they do.

Logjammin' was a better movie than The Big Lebowski.

Sorry, everyone.

Its just not a good movie.

Maude Lebowski: What do you do for recreation? The Dude: Oh, the usual. I bowl. Drive around. The occasional acid flashback.

That just about sums up this trip: Some bowling, where we meet one of the most interesting characters I have ever seen in Jesus Quintana (John Turturro), and where The Staranger (Sam Elliott) pops in from time to time to offer such sage advice as. "Sometimes you eat the bar, and sometimes, well, he eats you."

Some driving around in a comedy of errors where John Goodman really shines as Walter Sobchak. With friends like that, you certainly don't need enemies. We also meet really colorful characters like Maude Lebowski (Julianne Moore), who just wants The Dude's seed; Bunny Lebowski (Tara Reid), the porn star turned gold-digger; and, of course, The Big Lebowski (David Huddleston) and his faithful servant Brandt (Philip Seymour Hoffman). And when Steve Buscemi started talking about the In and Out Burger, I almost lost it. I swore he was going to go into "the old in and out" routine.

A visit to Jackie Treehorn (Ben Gazzara) brings about an amazing thing that could only be described as an acid flashback. I have to admit I had my mouth open the whole time it was going on. It was just that incredible.

You should get the idea that this is not a film about kidnapping and money and criminals; it was a film about the characters. i only touched on the main ones. There are plenty more interesting gems to find.

Only the Coen brothers could have dreamed up the story of a slacker caught up in a bad situation. It was one of the funniest films I have ever seen.

This movie creates its own niche. If I was looking at it objectively through a 2019 lens, cultural brainwashing would suggest this doesn't work. But when I originally saw it, not knowing what it was, I thought to myself, "ahh, now I understand". See it.

review_title: Hey! Easy does it! There's a beverage present here, man.
review_detailed_main:
The funniest part of this, 'down and outers' comedy is, that I know several guys, that if you took and rolled them into one, they would equal the Dude, Jeffrey LeBowski. that's pretty scary. I don't even think that they have seen the movie, but who cares?

Jeff Bridges is so stinking versatile I can't believe it from a reel-live slacker extraordinare to (The Big LeBowski 1998) a reel-President- (The Contender 2000) with out skipping a beat. For all intensive purposes this movie would be a real waste of time, but this was a side splitting whimsical good time!! From Julliane Moore as the egocentric, emotionally-sterile 'Maude' who was a suspicious investigator, to the best friend (Goodman) who's religious nationality 'changes' because of his 'Ex' who dumped him cold. But as long as he can 'bowl' with the Dude, all his other short-comings, just seem to go by the way-side. But through it all, he (Goodman's character) was a loyal buddy to Jeff and a decent friend, even if he could acquire 'fingers' by 3:00...with nail polish. In all fairness though, LeBowski as a 'private' investigator, reminds me of a quote from 'Dirty Harry' where Harry states (after the 'demise' of a man who is a victim of his own stupidity and greed) 'A man should know his own limitations.' and in this case, having Jeffrey investigate is just as swift as letting the 'fox' guard that Ole' hen house. This was a 'slackers delight' and watching someone who is as good a player as 'Bridges' play a tremendously convincing 'Loser' is just a rare treat. In the comedy section, this one is an ever so often player. Just one that you 'havfta see' every now and again. I don't know who he studied, but if I didn't know better I would swear that he got together with my two 'old school' buds. (****)

review_title: I don't know why its so good, it just is.
review_detailed_main: This is one of those films I watched because I thought I would look cool when I told my friends about it, but in fact I would not tell them about it because I wanted to keep it to myself. It captures a mood and tells a very simple story along the way. I watched Fargo and thought it was OK, but did not think it was that good, but this was just "The Dude".

review_title: Not outstanding (as a Coen brothers movie) but still worth watching.
This ol' movie really ties the collection together.
review_detailed_main:
Jeff Bridges is perfect as Jeff Lebowski, a.k.a. The Dude; he's an ageing, amiable slacker who doesn't do much with his time besides bowl. When he's mistaken for a rich man (David Huddleston) with the same name, he's hired by the rich man to deliver a ransom. Things go from bad to worse in a hurry, in large part because The Dude frequently involves his loud, abrasive buddy Walter (John Goodman), a crazed Vietnam vet, in his actions.

In terms of the overall Coen brothers filmography, this is relatively minor stuff. It goes on a little too long, and wasn't always terribly funny to this viewer. It also feels self-indulgent at times. And yet, Joel and Ethan here craft a twist-laden, elaborate story that does have some good moments, as well as a highly profane script and an eclectic soundtrack. (The Dude hates The Eagles, but is a big fan of CCR.) Its quotes certainly entered the public consciousness in a big way, with Bridges quickly becoming a pop culture icon in his role. "Well, you know, that's just like your opinion, man."

The main reason it worked to any degree (at least for this viewer) was because of its impressive and well-chosen cast: Sam Elliott (as a friendly narrator), Julianne Moore, Steve Buscemi (as in "Shut the *beep* up, Donny!"), Philip Seymour Hoffman, Tara Reid, Peter Stormare, David Thewlis, Flea, Ben Gazzara, Jon Polito, etc. John Turturro is such a hoot as a bowler named Jesus that it's too bad that his screen time is so limited.

"The Big Lebowski" is a truly character-driven comedy that does wrap up in a typically amusing way, and it shows that its main character can't just be dismissed as a non-thinking deadbeat; he knows when he's been used. It gave this viewer a conclusion that earned an honest smile, as Elliott breaks the fourth wall and comments on the nature of the yarn with which he's regaled us.

Seven out of 10.

The Big Lebowski is rare in the world of motion pictures. It's like a well written book (like Dune or LOTR) in that you can walk away with something new from it with each repeated viewing. The Cohen brothers put a lot of thought into their films, and the Big Lebowski is no exception.

Talking crap about a movie is the easiest thing to do, and I've read a few reviews that have done just that about Lebowski. In these people's defense, it's easy to jump to this conclusion because at first glance, it appears to be a meaningless film. But if it were meaningless, why set the film during the first Gulf War? Why do a period piece set 7 years before the movie's release? Because they're playing with allegory here, trying to say something about America.

There is much evidence of this. The perceptive viewer will note that we're dealing with clearly cut characters that embody archetypes of American culture. We're also dealing with events that mimic the political and sociological landscape of 1991. In addition, most period pieces splash nostalgia all over the screen, but there's hardly any in Lebowski. This movie is a humorous, tongue-in-cheek statement about the health of the American character circa 1991.

But even if you take the meaning of the movie out of the equation, The Big Lebowski is a top notch film. The characters and their interactions in the movie are entertaining. The direction plums the depths of their potential and brings it out for us to enjoy. The scenes work to promote the themes of the movie and give us a good laugh in the process. The Cohens did their job and then some on this one, and it seems to me like they had a damn good time doing it.

This is really a strange movie. But strange in a good way. It was so funny and entertaining and the characters were just outrageous. Being Swedish I of course enjoyed seeing Peter Stormare in a small role as a German nihilist fond of "lingonberry pancakes". I also thought Julianne Mores feministic character was very funny. John Goodman, Jeff Bridges and Steve Buscemi were all great in the leading roles. "The Big Lebowski" is without a doubt a really, really strange *and* a really, really funny movie. It must be seen to be believed!

You: I have never seen "The Big Lebowski." Me: Shut the **** up, Donny. You: I'm sorry...? Me: You're outta your element!!! You: You're scaring me now. Me: Ha! It don't matter to Jesus! You: What? Listen, who do you think you are? Me: I'm The Dude...that's what you call me! You: Okay, "Dude", I am hanging up now. Me: And a good day to you sir! -Click!- 10 seconds later.... Ring ring ring ring ring "Phone's ringin', Dude! This was an imaginary conversation between me and anyone who has not seen "The Big Lebowski." So, please. Save yourself a lot of trouble and see the movie. You do not want this conversation to happen to you. What can I say that hasn't already been said about this film? Nuthin'. You'll just have to see it for yourself.

John Goodman's character impressed me more than the Dude did. Because he is funnier & deep.

Following the story of how a slacker and his bowling club friends fall into a parade of crime is written with humor in mind. The characters are very different & genuine from each other. The boldness is another thing to consider. Great music playing as the background score, there are few moments when it comes to total laugh out. The thought of these sequences will make you laugh. Improbable situations deliberately brought out by the characters will feed you with story, narration & food for thought.

Lengthening the plot a bit and shut-up ending makes me feel not totally satisfied by the dude & his chums. I'll rate a humble 6.5/10 for the gang and the eclectic characters, music & setups. Very impressed as this is my first film by Coen Brothers. Steve Buscemi is good while Jeff Bridges is cool as hell.

BOTTOM LINE: Extremely funny for people who can relate. Moderately funny for people who enjoy logical scripts.

Can be watched with a typical Indian family? NO

review_title: it's a waste of time.right DUDE?
review_detailed_main:
I was quite interested in watching it.I thought it would be a 2 hours of laughter marathon.In the end i realized i didn't even laugh a single time.

the whole story is hardly bears any meaning and there were some jokes i didn't get at all.

One more important point is IMDb has been very poor in case of judging comedies.I just found "Monty Python and the holy grail" the same boring as Big Lebowski.

So,don't be fooled by rating like me.

My rating is 1(aweful)

Film very messed up, very strange and very beautiful where the protagonist literally does nothing but in any case all the events of the story "invest" him without any mercy. The film ranges between different genres and generally follows very well.

review_title: Buy yourself the DVD and keep it.
review_detailed_main: This is a mad film that everyone should watch at least once - with a year between viewings - so that each time more of the movie and ALL of it's character's foibles are able to be ingested. The leads are all in superb form and carry along the madcap theme of the central roles of an indoor bowling-mad trio of unfriendly friends. Great stuff.

Before I delve right into the review I have to say that I am great bowling fan and play it from time to time with some of my friends. Yet, I didn't saw THE BIG LEBOWSKI until last April, and when I finally did, I knew I would have loved it. As there are to date 1401 reviews I'll be short.

Jeffrey Lebowski known as the Dude (Jeff Bridges) is a slacker that spends most of his days in his robe and going bowling with his friends Walter Sobchak (John Goodman) and Theodore Donald Kerabatsos (Steve Buscemi). One day the Dude is assaulted by two enforcers sent by an adult movie kingpin Jackie Treehorn (Ben Gazzara) despite they realize after a rug accident that they got the wrong man with the same name. After various accidents and misunderstandings, the Dude and his pals will do everything for giving the ransom money and go out of the mess.

I'll talk about what I loved: Jeff Bridges gives probably his greatest performance of his colorful career, and he nailed the good-hearted slacker part well. John Goodman is also great as the obsessed Vietnam war veteran and Steve Buscemi? He gives his usual likeable performance as the guy with always the right catchphrase in the right moment. The rest (Julianne Moore, Peter Stormare, Flea, Ben Gazzara, Phillip Seymour Hoffman) is good but not as great as our three heroes. The soundtrack is very 1990s and the script witty and full of funny moments.

So, if you still haven't seen this movie, rush for it if you have the chance because it's one of those classics with a huge enjoyability factor. My only warning (and also my friend Martin Hafer said it), but still is very minor, is the language that might be too rough for younger viewers. Still, a real must see.

Every so often, I need to watch this movie. At first it was because I would be in need of a laugh. Now it's like chicken soup for the soul. I will admit, first time I watched it, I thought it was ok, but it needs a second viewing, a deeper viewing. That's when you will realise how much you love it. It's a film filled with career best (and loveable) performances. Particularly from Jeff Bridges, John Goodman and an insane performance from John Turturro. Also Sam Elliot's stranger is the standard that all narration should be held to. His final speach in this movie makes me smile and cry at the same time. I can only hope that someone will say something as beautiful at my funeral.

Being a staunch opponent of drug use, this brand of humor doesn't usually suit my bill, but it is still one of the funniest movies I have seen recently. The camaraderie between Bridges, Goodman, and (kind of) Buscemi is excellent, although Buscemi's portrayal of the idiotic, unaware friend got old very quickly. Perhaps the funniest scene in the whole movie is Moore's character flying overhead to squirt paint on her abstract art... after reading that her character was influenced by Yoko Ono, it couldn't be more hilarious and true. I did love the cinematography and lighting, as well as the frequent dives into psychedelic episodes. The transitions into those scenes were especially well executed. All in all, the characters were casted near perfectly, and the constant juxtaposition of a stoner and Hollywood drama sequences was hilarious... that's what works with this movie. The bare concept is so hilarious that the entire movie is just soaking it all in, and even then it isn't overdone. The biggest surprise of this movie is that some of the humor is quite sophisticated, although there are plenty of the hackneyed stoner jokes as well. For those who appreciate a good comedy and can handle a boatload of profanity, this movie is for you.

review_title: The first time I see something that makes me happy
review_detailed_main: Every time I think of laughing, I smile and make it very simple, and it leaves me with a wide smile. It does not separate me. It makes me very deaf just for thinking, not watching. I recommend it to all people. Watch it. You like it. The feeling that I felt at the time.

review_title: A Humorous Dark Coen Brothers Film
review_detailed_main:
Today I saw "The Big Lebowski" for the first time. Somehow I missed this movie in 1998 and never saw it on DVD in the years after its release. About the only thing that I knew about the film was that Jeff Bridges was "The Dude". Now I know the rest of the story.

Before moving on, I'll offer up this quick disclaimer: This is in no way a family friendly film. That should be expected from the Coen Brothers, but since I went into it not knowing what to expect at all, and my only perception of the film being that it was mostly a comedy, I thought that it might be somewhat lighter than most of the Coens' stable of films. And it was. But there's still language throughout the movie, along with some fairly adult themes at points. Several times along the way I found myself feeling that this was the Coens' answer to "Pulp Fiction" (the chasing of the brief case, the remark about the quality of the In-n-Out Burger, the fact that Bridges dresses like Travolta and Jackson at the end of PF, etc.).

The film is quite funny, in that dark style of humor that the Coens are known for. Sometimes the humor is so prevalent that it becomes banal. Nevertheless the film does feature quite a few good laughs. But then mixed in with those laughs are the odd Coen Brothers moments, such as what I'll call "the ear scene", in which the mixture of humor and horror blends in a way that challenges the viewer's comfort.

My main beef with this film is that it doesn't end with a resolution. Yes, all ends well (Spoiler alert, but "The Dude Abides"). Still, you never find out what happens to the briefcase or whether it had money in it (another similarity to Pulp Fiction). The situation with Bunny sort of gets forgotten, too. All in all the ending of the film just felt anticlimactic to me.

I nevertheless did enjoy the movie, though. It is what it is, a Coen Brothers film that makes you laugh all while pushing boundaries. Still just as there are Elvis people and Beatles people, I think that there are Coen Bros. people and Tarrantino people, and I'm a Tarrantino person. So I think I'm going to go with 7/10 stars. Enjoyed it, but not in my top tier.

review_title: Surprised I Haven't Seen This Already
review_detailed_main:
I really liked this movie. When I told my professor I just watched it for the first time he was surprised because this is a "classic." I see why you can call it that if you saw this when it first came out. Watching it for the first time now and I thought it was really funny, had some really quotable moments, and there were a lot of creative and well-written characters.

John Goodman and Jeff Bridges had good performances. John Goodman was surprisingly hilarious and I really enjoyed the scenes with Steve Buscemi's character and the three of them at the bowling alley a lot. I have never seen Jeff Bridges in this type of role and I thought he was really funny and really personified The Dude character well. The plot doesn't take itself too seriously and it is a good movie to just turn on and enjoy.

Overall, The Big Lebowski was a really good movie and I recommend checking it out. It was a really well-made comedy and the characters had depth and were fun to watch. The Dude lowkey reminded me of one of my professors that I have had with the way he dressed and walked. Not necessarily his whole personality but parts about him. Also the cardigan The Dude wears at the end is fire. Iconic look.
The beauty of the Coen brothers The Big Lebowski is that they're able to make a movie that's basically about nothing and make it so watchable to the point where it's become a classic

This had got to be one of the best films ever. It stars some of film's legends: John Goodman, Jeff Bridges and Steve Buscemi.

They play a bunch of misfit losers caught up in a bad situation involving underworld figures. There's so much style and sophistication in the writing and cinematography. The director creates comedic moments you never saw coming.

There are one liners you'll find yourself remembering and chuckling to yourself as you fall asleep.

And the central character is played masterfully by Jeff Bridges- "the Dude"- a kahlua-loving dead-beat who just wants to go bowling and slouch around. Brilliant!

When a couple of guys pee on the dude's rug everything goes out of control. And I do mean everything. Backed up by his two Bowling buddies, Donny the looser and Walter the Crazy veteran, the dude gets pulled into a chain of events which drags him through the movie. The leading Bridges/Goodman/Buscemi trio is outstanding, both Bridges and Goodman's best performances as actors, Buscemi only bettered this one in Fargo. The screenplay is hilarious, every line is a joke. The supporting actors are as good as the main trio. I've watched this movie over a dozen times and I'm still discovering new jokes. This is really a masterpiece, it just keeps getting better and better.

And swears a lot - and of course there is alcohol and other drugs involved too. I did not remember the small amount of nudity we do get to see - it had been way too long since I last watched this. And while I remember having issues with the humor in Fargo (the expecting the "unexpected"), I know I really dug this. Still I have to rewatch Fargo some day - and then go on with the TV show they made too of course.

But back to this - you cannot be easily offended. So much swearing ... so many weird characters (all played by really good actors most would say, even Tara Reid and her short stint in this work more than swell) ... so much craziness. And an episodic journey with his Dudeness. Jeff Bridges has done so many good movies, but this is the one movie he mostly will be remembered for. And he doesn't mind - why should he? Such a fun and over the top script and movie has to be cherished.

There are so many iconic scenes, so many quotable things - from the STFU Donny, which is used so many times, to the "this is what happens when you ... a man in the ..." - something I can't write here, because the review would therefor not be allowed to exist. And then the iconic car missing scene. Which sprang the title for "Dude where's my car" ... at least that's how the story goes.

The movie may be 2 hours long, but at no time did I feel the length of it ... wait, that may be a pun? Not as obvious as Jesus cleaning his (bowling) ball ... but still! Also nobody ... with the Jesus! I almost want to check the quotes section imdb has for the movie ... so many things they cannot write I assume.

Anyway, the movie is far out and if you don't like, than I would say: That is very undude of you Dude!

I found that while I liked certain parts of the film and found the acting excellent. It just seemed uneven in pace and plot...

...however...

Five days later, I found himself quoting lines from the movie and laughing to myself about many of the scenes. Call it the "slow-burn effect", it just gets better with age.

It was a much better film than I though it was when I first saw it. However, it is a 8-9 star movie. But since I didn't realize it in the beginning while I viewed it, I had to dock it a couple of stars.

Definitely part of the Cohen Canon. This is a Good Thing.

I don't roll on Shabbos!!

review_title: The best hour and 45 minutes of your life!!!!
review_detailed_main:
The Big Lebowski is one of the most talked about comedies ever created. When I first saw it I hated it. Then a year later I ended up re-watching it, and liking it. Then loving it. Then I was hooked.

The movie opens up with some old random dude telling us a story. He explained all about his fascination with the Dude. Then we see how the story all begins. In the middle we meet a lot of bizarre characters such as the laughing man, the fat boring kid, the nazi/analysts, and the bald guy in the little buggy.

By the end of the movie you will probably dislike or be confused with the film but by the 4th time around, you wont ever understand how you could ever dislike it!

review_title: One of the most original, unique movies of recent years. *** (out of four)
review_detailed_main:
THE BIG LEBOWSKI / (1998) *** (out of four)

By Blake French:

The Coen Brothers are an artistic breed of their own. They add a twisted touch of humor to every project. They create imaginative characters, memorable stories, and ingenious dialogue. They have explored the lives of poets, hillbillies, cops, mobsters, adulterers, killers, and now a loser.

That's right, "The Big Lebowski" explores the life of a big-time loser. A lazy, uninspiring, unemployed loser. His name is Jeff Lebowski (Jeff Bridges), who lives in the moment and wears a goatee, a beer belly, a ponytail, and a pair of oversized Bermuda shorts. He lives to bowl, drink White Russians, and to do drugs. (Character: What do you do for recreation? The Dude: Oh, the usual. Bowl, drive around. The occasional acid flashback).

The Dude's best bowling pals, Donny (Steve Buscemi), who is never allowed to finish a sentence, and Walter (John Goodman), who is stuck in the past, diddle with the Dude as he goes with the flow, inhibiting not a care in the world. Until a porn king confuses the Dude for another person with the same name of Lebowski. Thugs invade the Dude's house, plunge his head into the toilet, and pee on his rug. They leave after they realize they have mistaken his identity.

However, the Dude wants a new rug. Walter and The Dude take a trip to the rich Lebowski's. They get more than a rug. It appears that someone has kidnapped Lebowski's daughter and the wealthy bigwig wants the Dude to deliver the ransom money. The Dude agrees, and, of course, chaos ensues.

Some of the material falls flat. A subplot about a bowling maniac named Jesus (John Turrturo) goes absolutely nowhere. Fortunately, many scenes work wonderfully, featuring original ideas, thought-provoking metaphors, experimental camera techniques, and eye-popping cinematography. I especially enjoyed how the film explores the Dude's dreams with sequences bursting with color, imagination, and peculiar images.

Audiences will remember "The Big Lebowski" as one of the most imaginative films of the decade. The Coen brothers create an odd assortment of unique circumstances and characters. The quirky characters have lots of fun with the unbelievably profane, (Screenit.com informs us that the movie uses the "F" word 250+ times!), but strangely amusing dialogue.

What does it all add up to? Well, there is plenty to think about and plenty to laugh at, but we do not leave with a powerful feeling of satisfaction. "The Big Lebowski" may resemble the spirit of "Raising Arizona," another wildly funny comedy by the Coen's, but this movie's does not quite work as well. Both contain the same zany style, but that film felt inspired by plot. "The Big Lebowski" lacks plot. A string of amusing predicaments does not necessarily account for the absence of story.

If the film would have followed a clear, comprehensible story, it may have been more involving, but that's clearly not what the Coen brother's wanted. Even before the opening credits begin, the film's narrator (Sam Elliot) explains that this film is about the Dude's adventures. It's not really a narrative of the Dude, but an examination of his reaction to life changing events. By the end of the movie, we sense the Dude has learned from his experiences, and because of them, he is a better personwell, kind of.

review_title: "That rug really tied the room together, did it not?"

review_detailed_main:
My Dad absolutely loves this film; it speaks to him on a spiritual level or something. I personally don't understand the humour, and, when I do, find it too subtle to be funny. However The Big Lebowski doesn't fit into any other category of movie, so -- what is it?

For me it was a disappointment, it having been so hyped up by my Dad. For others it was an absolute triumph, if you're into that kind of film. It takes a very specific person to enjoy a movie like that, but, if you do, it will certainly be one of your favourites. I guess it's much like Marmite, a kind of love-it hate-it situation. Personally I saw the funny side of it, and the reasons for it being such a cult classic, but it just didn't fit my style.

Watch Fargo instead. If you've seen it, watch it again, and then think "could the Coen brothers outdo themselves?" If the answer is no, don't spoil your own opinion of them by seeing this film. If you think they could do something more out-there or interesting, sure give The Big Lebowski a go.
Was there a scene where you laughed? I wish I would spend my time astral traveling.

The Big Lebowski is a movie to watch again and again - and yet enjoy its subtle humour and great atmosphere everytime. The Coen Brother's truely are great filmmakers - constantly providing us with witty, original scripts and deep memorable characters.

The Big Lebowski - as with all the Coen films - is driven by sharp dialogue and excellent characters. The 'Dude' is the personification of laziness acted to perfection by Jeff Bridges, always wearing the same tatty clothes and hilariously drinking a milky White Russian "Hey man i got a beverage here!" We first meet the Dude in a shopping mall - with milk on his moustache - hilariously writing a cheque for 69cents! John Goodman is the Jewish Vietnam veteran Walter Schobchek - taking every opportunity to shout about his dead 'buddies' from the war and shout at Donny (Steve Buchemi). Donny is a quiet man with very little impact on the narrative - however the comedic relationship between him, Walter and the 'Dude' is a charm.

The atmosphere created here gives superb viewing, with top notch cinematography and genuine, if obscure, relationships between the odd characters. But what you will remember most from this film are the hilarious quotations - "F*** it dude, let go bowling", "Well thats just, like, your opinion man!" and "Obviously your not privy to the new s**t, man" to name just a couple.

this is a great movie with no flaws (my opinion of course) also the performances were impeccable. although no awards or nominations were given it was still great. this is a movie you can watch over and over again. and still laugh every time. but this movie is not for some people like those who are contradictical of bowling, drugs, kidnappings, crime or nudity, it received and deserved it's r rating. that statement is mabey the only negativity i'll do on such a great film. but to e honest i almost didn't see this, on account of i thought it would be completely different, and because of no nominations of any awards, but this movie actually has made me think outside of the box for movies why else would i see malibu's most wanted.

review_title: The Funniest Film of All Time
review_detailed_main: The first time I saw The Big Lebowski, I was incapable of speaking during the movie. It was literally so hilarious that I could do nothing but laugh during its running time; at some points, I was laughing so hard that I nearly fell off of my chair and tears ran down my face. I had already seen several Coen Brothers films before seeing this movie, including the masterpiece Fargo and the hilarious Raising Arizona, so I had high expectations going in. These expectations were more than exceeded; they were shattered by non-stop laughter. John Goodman gives perhaps the funniest performance in any movie I've ever seen and Jeff Bridges IS the Dude; nobody else could have played that role. The day after seeing it for the first time I watched it again, and it was even funnier than the first time, if that is possible. In the multiple viewings since then, I am still laughing out loud and finding new quotable lines. The Big Lebowski is rare in that it is not just hysterical but it is also smart. While I enjoy stupid comedies like Zoolander and Dumb and Dumber, it is so much better when the humor is both hilarious and clever. The Big Lebowski is the funniest movie I've ever seen and one of my all time favorites. I give it my highest recommendation: 10/10.

This film still blows me away even after about 30 viewings! It is a blend of film noir/detective film(The BIG SLEEP, Maltese Falcon/All Through the Night)/comedy. The funny thing about it is you don't even realize that it is a detective film until you've seen it 2-3 times. I was loosely aware but it really sank in after the 3rd viewing! (i'm slow, i know) "The Dude"(Jeff Bridges)is in just about every scene, if not every scene. You get so caught up in watching him, his "laid backness", and his compatriots that you forget they are actually involved in trying to negotiate a ransom drop and recover a kidnap victim.

"The Dude" is a reluctant hero along the lines of "Rick" from "Casablanca". Although not so self centered and altruistic as "Rick", it is evident from the start that "The Dude" would much rather be bowling and have a drink(a "White Russian", or as he called it, "a Caucasian") than have the responsibility of saving anyone's life.

There may not be as many classic lines in this film as there are in the great films I compared it to above,but there are as many, if not more lines that get quoted by those who know and love this film.

The last time I saw this(Big Lebowski) I kept asking myself what film does it remind me of the most? Then it hit me..."The Big Sleep". ;)

This has never been my type of comedy. I'm not a Cohen Bros kind of guy. I was in the mood to watch this for the first time the other night, 20 years later.

I love Jeff Bridges' character. He is great. I love John Goodman as an actor but his character here was more annoying than anything. I think Steve Buscemi's character should have been more developed and involved, and taken some screen time from Goodman. A little Goodman in this character would have been hilarious but not overly played out.

Sometimes there's a film... I won't say a masterpiece, 'cause, what's a masterpiece? But sometimes, there's a film. And I'm talking' about The Big Lebowski here. Sometimes, there's a film, well, it's the film for its time and place. It fits right in there. Hardcore film nerd or not, many of us probably have a go-to film that we've seen countless times and know the lines almost by heart, but still enjoy it as much every time. Well, to me, The Big Lebowski is that film.

Trying to deconstruct what is so funny or brilliant about it is probably somewhat counterproductive, but I will say that it is one of the best scripts I have ever seen, and the characters as well as the cast behind them are nothing short of perfection. And most of all, it is so insanely entertaining and quotable.

"You know, he's got emotional problems, man."

"You mean beyond pacifism?"

I didn't see The Big Lebowski upon its original release but more recently i decided it was time I checked out what seems to have become a major cult classic for many. In the folks I spoke with I think it's the actual character that inspires, excites, and evokes such devotion amongst them. This I can kind of understand. But with the film as a whole there's a bit of a divergence. The film itself is basically fine. With the exception of a few specifics the story isn't that original but what is unique in this story is the strong central characters (The Dude) reaction to/and handling of those situations and scenarios. Yes, Jeff Bridges does a great job create a unique and believable character in The Dude, but the film he inhabits is just fine. Check it out and see what you think.

I bought this movie before i watched it and i am very glad that i did. this movie was so good but you can not fully appreciate all the jokes and humor until you see it 2 or even three times but you still will get your laughs on your first time. i went to California this year and i couldn't leave without a Ralph's card or a visit or two to the In-n-out burger which has fantastic food. i highly recommend this movie to anyone. if you don't understand this movie you just haven't watched it enough or payed attention.

you can pick this movie up pretty cheap from most movie stores it is definitely a good investment to your movie collection.

Very offbeat, highly original movie that provides tie ins for mistaken identity, some effective and hilarious characters and off the wall situations. Unpredictable and free spirited, the "Dude", our protagonist gets caught in a web of intrigue. This intrigue seemingly and annoyingly takes him away from his happy life of apathy, unemployment and bowling. THE BIG LEBOWSKI is strictly Coen Brothers madness, in the vein of RAISING ARIZONA. The visuals, dream sequences, et al, are very funny and fit well in the movie. Unfortunately, the last half starts to slow down, as the characters start to seem repetitive in their reactions. The humor also waned, due to this, and the plot, not the film's strong suit to begin with, wears down with it. THE BIG LEBOWSKI is still yards ahead of most mainstream releases, yet we've grown rather accustomed (even spoiled) to expect so much more from the Coens. Recommended.

review_title: One of the greatest ever and the dude abides 9/10
review_detailed_main: "The Big Lebowski" is considered to be among the best movies ever made. The Coen brothers have wrote and directed a wonderful epic movie that has a huge fan base till this day. Centered around a figure called "the dude" who finds himself in an unlikely weird adventure consisting of neo nazis, thugs, a big scam, dirty undies and bowling. Jeffrey Lebowski (Jeff Bridges) is the dude and the perfect example of an unemployed bachelor middle aged guy who's life style is mostly cannabis and bowling. Jeff Bridges gives what is probably his best performance in a movie ever, and it is known for being his most iconic role ever. John Goodman also gives a wonderful and amazing performance as Walter Sobchak and is mostly hilarious in the film. Gets all the good lines. The film stars other great and well actors: Steve Buscemi, Julianne Moore, John Turturro, Phillip Seymour Hoffman and Sam Elliott. What I love mostly about the film is it's empty plot. Of course there is a lot going on but there are so many bizarre things happening that it doesn't matter anymore what the film's about, nor what are the films motives. In one opening scene you get an introduction to the character and how two thugs ruin his rug. In another scene the dude's car is stolen. Afterwards the characters go investigate a teenager and end up ruining somebody else's car. The point is that the plot is not important, the movie draws most of its magic from the characters and their interactions. Which to me is an important key role in movies to have characters who are fun and have many things happening to them. At the end of the day this is probably one of the best movies ever made and the dude abides on that. Now let's go bowling.

I loved the Coens previous film, Fargo. I can see a lot of similarities between the two films. The Big Lebowski has a lot more humor than Fargo. Jeff Bridges was perfectly cast as Jeff The Dude Lebowski who gets confused with a millionaire of the same name. He gets caught up in a kidnapping and ransom scheme of a trophy wife. The cast is brilliant with John Goodman and Steve Buscemi as the Dude's best friends and bowling buddies. Julianne Moore is particularly memorable as Maude Lebowski. David Huddleston played Jeff Lebowski is also memorable. Phillip Seymour Hoffman played Brandt, his assistant. The film is really a great film for the guys in general. Sam Elliott is memorable as the narrator,

This is one of the greatest movies of all time. The Dude is Jeff Bridges premier role and its rewatchable multiple times. Just love everything about it. It has so many outstanding moments. Genius movie and I love this movie to bits. Classic.

review_title: Embracing Eccentricity, Absurdity, and Counterculture with Unforgettable Charm
review_detailed_main:
"The Big Lebowski," directed by the Coen Brothers, stands as a remarkable cinematic achievement, deserving its place as a true masterpiece. With its idiosyncratic characters, witty dialogue, and unparalleled blend of genres, the film has garnered a dedicated following and achieved cult status. Through its unique storytelling, exceptional performances, and offbeat humor, "The Big Lebowski" cements its reputation as a cinematic gem that continues to captivate and entertain audiences.

At the heart of "The Big Lebowski" lies a colorful cast of characters brought to life by an ensemble cast that delivers pitch-perfect performances. Jeff Bridges shines as the iconic slacker hero, The Dude, exuding a laid-back charisma that makes him instantly endearing. The film also boasts memorable supporting performances from John Goodman, Steve Buscemi, and Julianne Moore, who each bring their distinct quirks and comedic timing to their respective roles. The Coen Brothers' sharp and witty dialogue infuses every scene with memorable lines that have become cultural touchstones, further contributing to the film's enduring popularity.

"The Big Lebowski" weaves a delightfully absurd narrative that effortlessly blends elements of film noir, comedy, and surrealism. The Coen Brothers' masterful storytelling takes viewers on a wild ride through a labyrinthine plot involving mistaken identity, a missing rug, and a ransom scheme. Amidst the chaos and confusion, the film maintains a remarkable sense of coherency, revealing deeper themes of existentialism, identity, and the unpredictable nature of life. The intricate layers of the narrative encourage repeated viewings, offering new insights and discoveries with each watch.

The Coen Brothers' craftsmanship is on full display in "The Big Lebowski," with their meticulous attention to detail evident in every frame. The film's visual style perfectly complements its offbeat tone, showcasing the Coens' mastery of visual storytelling. Through inventive camera work, clever editing, and evocative production design, they create a distinct visual language that immerses viewers in the film's quirky world. From dream sequences to bowling alley escapades, the Coens' visual flair adds an extra layer of richness to the film's overall experience.

"The Big Lebowski" embraces and celebrates eccentricity, counterculture, and the beauty of embracing one's own idiosyncrasies. The film's subversive humor and irreverent spirit serve as a commentary on societal norms and expectations. The Dude's nonchalant attitude towards life becomes a symbol of resistance against conformity, inspiring audiences to embrace their individuality and find humor in the face of adversity. This underlying message of authenticity and the celebration of the unconventional is what truly sets "The Big Lebowski" apart.

Since its release, "The Big Lebowski" has gained a dedicated and passionate cult following, with annual events, fan conventions, and even its own religion (Dudeism) dedicated to its legacy. Its impact on popular culture is undeniable, with countless references and memes permeating the media landscape. The film's enduring popularity is a testament to its ability to resonate with audiences on a deeply personal level, celebrating the joy of embracing life's absurdities and finding solace in unlikely places.

"The Big Lebowski" is a cinematic masterpiece that defies traditional genre boundaries, offering a quirky and unforgettable experience that has captivated audiences worldwide. With its memorable characters, witty dialogue, intricate storytelling, and distinctive visual style, the film leaves an indelible mark on the cinematic landscape. The Coen Brothers' masterful direction, combined with the exceptional performances from the cast, creates a truly unique and captivating cinematic experience.

"The Big Lebowski" is more than just a film; it is a cultural phenomenon that continues to inspire and entertain. Its status as a cult classic is a testament to its enduring appeal and the profound impact it has had on popular culture. From its quotable lines to its unapologetic celebration of eccentricity and counterculture, the film invites audiences to embrace their own individuality and find humor in life's absurdities.

As a cinematic masterpiece, "The Big Lebowski" stands as a testament to the power of creativity, imagination, and the ability of film to transcend conventional storytelling. It reminds us that cinema has the remarkable ability to transport us to extraordinary worlds, challenge our perspectives, and ignite our imaginations.

In the pantheon of great films, "The Big Lebowski" has rightfully earned its place. Its blend of comedy, mystery, and social commentary, paired with its unforgettable characters and offbeat charm, solidify its status as a timeless masterpiece. Whether you're a first-time viewer or a dedicated fan, "The Big Lebowski" continues to delight, entertain, and provoke thought, cementing its legacy as an enduring classic of cinema.

I was very disappointed. I really liked Fargo, and so many people I know had such good comments on this film, but I find it just dumb and somewhat predictable.

The characters, "Dude" and Walter are great, though. They are complex and interesting. Yet I find the plot...although it's complex and full of twists, ...mainly bland and forgettable. The story starts to become messy,really messy after an hour an a half, and you start getting that "anything goes now" feeling. And what's with Dude's constant "trips"/dreams? They are not funny, and they only detract from the story.

Is it supposed i have to laugh with the most ridiculous and stupid characters i've ever seen? I hope not. I'd say it's the most stupid movie i've ever seen. There is no hidden humor, or smart comedy. Everything goes around the big dude. Or I'd say, the big asshole! The movie itself is a comedy, it is a parody of a comedy. I have no clue why people loved this movie so much. I start seeing the movie because of that and I've to say it was a complete disappoint. How someone can laugh with such a bad movie? No clue, if someone can explain me that I'd really appreciate it. The big fraud, the big piece pf crap, the big plot without any story... all of them would be really nice names for this movie. Make yourself a favor and don't miss your time seeing this movie.

review_title: Much more than just a comedy - a genre-spanning masterwork.
review_detailed_main:
It's a rare thing when movies like this come along. It's the kind of picture where you'll either marvel at the highly woven plot and genre-hopping genius, or deplore it for being a completely random, stupid and unfathomable piece of crap.

The Dude (Jeff Bridges) is an iconic, laconic slacker. Instantly likable, the Dude's own slant on life is that most things can be solved by taking it easy or going bowling. His partners in crime are Walter; a deranged 'Nam verteran (John Goodman in superb scene-stealing form), Donny, one of his bowling buddies (Steve Buscemi in an understated role) and David Huddleston as the title character, complete with assistant Brandt (Philip Seymour Hoffman, turning the smarm right up to ten). What starts as a simple case of mistaken identity and damaged property quickly becomes a roller-coaster tale of backstabbing and caricature characterisation which gets faster and more twisted as it reaches the final minutes.

The first time I saw this I must say, it just seemed ludicrous and not at all humorous. I wasn't really sure whether it wanted to be a comedy or a surreal drama. After getting about two thirds of the way through I got up and walked out, convinced that this was the worst film in the Coen brothers canon. But on a second viewing I stopped taking this film too seriously and it was then the offbeat comedy and plot really came together.

Ingenious, hilarious and unexpected you really don't have a clue what is going to happen, but the direction and cinematography make it seem like it was inevitable all along. Challenging and rewarding.

With characters ranging from Walter Sobchak, the angry Vietnam vet to Jackie Treehorn, the infamous pornographer, this film has it all. I often find myself repeating lines from this movie to my friends, just because they will be forever impounded in my mind. No matter how many times I watch it, I will still laugh at every scene. For my money, this is the greatest comedy ever produced.

This film not only provides non-stop laughter, but it teaches us an important lesson about life. We must adopt the Dude's carefree attitude. This movie teaches us that all you need in life are a few good friends and a recreational activity in which you enjoy greatly, in the Dude's case, bowling was what he enjoyed the most. Whether we put this lesson to use ourselves or not, it's like the Stranger said, `It's good knowin' he's out there. The Dude. Takin' 'er easy for all us sinners.'

review_title: The film with the highest rewatch factor of all time.

review_detailed_main:
This is already a cult film and one of the most delicious black comedies from the Coen brothers, with a luxury cast, led by Jeff Bridges, who plays a memorable role. But the star of the company is undoubtedly John Goodman, who has one of the best characters of his career here, without forgetting the inevitable John Turturro (the Coens' fetish actor) who, even reduced to a small role, gives a memorable and hilarious performance, and even Julianne Moore, who plays an unbelievable character.

An anti film noir, or if you prefer, a film noir dressed in pink, like the fantastic latin character Jesus, played by Turturro.

Simply hilarious.

review_title: A worse movie by Coen brothers

review_detailed_main: Such an empty boring film, some parts are fun (which brings up my review a little) but you can't excuse the entire film because some scenes have good writing. Non of the characters develop through the film at all they are the same characters you saw at the start. The plot doesn't develop or change past the 30 minute mark. The main character goes through the entire film not affecting the plot at all he is just there for the ride and there is no major payoff too.

So I finally watched this film a few weeks ago (in 2022) and this film was not at all funny. I smoke marijuana regularly and enjoy some stoner films, but damn this was just boring. I also like bowling and I'm Jewish so I really thought it would resonate. But maybe too much time has passed and that style of comedy is no longer humorous unless it's pressing your nostalgia buttons. Glad I watched after many years but I didn't miss anything.

Stars: Jeff Bridges, John Goodman, Steve Buscemi, David Huddleston, Julianne Moore, Phillip Seymour Hoffman, Peter Stormare, Flea, Torsten Voges, John Turturro, Sam Elliot, Tara Reid, Jack Kehler.

Many obviously consider this to be a classic. I don't consider it one, but I still found it very entertaining and was not disappointed. Our basic plot is stoner and loser Jeffrey "The Dude" Lebowski is mistaken for millionaire Jeffrey Lebowski, when men break in to his house and pee on his rug. To get the money for the rug The Dude goes to Jeffrey Lebowski, and ends up on a mission to find rich Lebowski's kidnapped wife. The movie is fairly fast paced, but that doesn't stop it from having periods of heavy clever dialogue, mostly between John Goodman as the ex-Vietnam veteran Walter and the Dude. Many of the film's most entertaining scenes are located in the bowling alley where The Dude, Walter and Donnie (Buscemi) talk about nothing and (of course) bowl. The backup cast is really good also, including Julianne Moore as the "kidnapped" wife and John Turturro as a sex offender bowler. Though I don't consider this to be a great classic film, it's still a good, fun movie with enough gusto to keep the whole thing afloat.

My rating: *** out of ****. 113 mins. R for sexuality/nudity, violence, drug use and language.

Sometimes the film is so good you have to say something. Sometimes the film is so bad you have to say something. Unfortunately it is the latter in this case.

I finally started to watch The Big Lebowski. Great reviews everywhere. Have to watch it. It is one of Coen brothers movies. It is rated almost five stars in Amazon. It is rated 8.2 on IMDb. It has to be good, right?

Not quite. I couldn't finish it - I had to stop watching it.

In the beginning you see a resemblance in the style of this movie and a lot of Quentin Tarantino's movies. I don't know if Coen brothers are borrowing from Quentin Tarantino, or if it's the other way around, but there seems to be plenty of resemblance to this film and Tarantino's films in general.

The best Coen brothers movie that they made was Fargo, and maybe it was so good because it was based on a true story. But for this, The Big Lebowski, it reeked of stupidity...but without comedy. It seemed to border on fantasy and improbability.

Really liked this movie, I heard from a friend that this was his favorite movie so I thought I'd give it a chance. It's a movie that I would watch multiple times because apart from the great plot it was also very funny and the music was well chosen. Jeff Bridges makes you believe that he really is "The Dude", and you start too sympathize with him even though he is a lazy unemployed man. When the film started with a voice-over of an old man i thought "oh this is gonna be so long and boring", but it wasn't until 5 minutes later that I totally changed my mind, and I was sucked into the story-line . I gave this film eight stars and I would definitely recommend it.

review_title: You need to see the world through the Dude's eyes
review_detailed_main: To enjoy this film you need to have a little bit of that hippie mentality. The people who doesn't get why this movie is great are the ones who lacks that. The Dude is a simple person with simple needs and he's just fine the way he is. His life is not about money, or chasing the american dream, to get a family, an expensive car, or to be that successful man in the suit. And it's all cool man. He has his own code of living. He should be a life coach imo, because he has nothing, but still has everything he needs. Especially that rug, that tied the room together...

This film is, to me, a masterpiece. The dude exemplifies what humans are lacking generally. I totally get that there are many people that don't get it, of course they don't... I assume they were hoping for a slapstick generic comedy. This has style and finesse, that is unique and makes me happy. If you do get it, you can watch it over and over, at least once a year for a top up. ... Absolutely brilliant!

review_title: One of the Great Cult Classics
review_detailed_main:
The Big Lebowski is perhaps the most surreal film from the Coen brothers, who have made their careers on surreal, dark comedies. There are numerous diversions, but the main plot is a take on ransom films. The film would have been a massive failure if not for some key performances. Jeff Bridges is The Dude, a.k.a. Jeff Lebowski, who is mistaken for a millionaire of the same name whose wife owes money to a pornographer. The Dude is an unemployed layabout who bowls with his two friends Walter and Donny. Walter is played by John Goodman, who portrays the character as a short-tempered Vietnam vet who uses his military service to justify his behavior. He constantly yells at Donny (Steve Buscemi) for no real reason, and waves guns at minor bowling infractions. The Dude finds himself caught up in the Big Lebowski's ransom as the millionaire hires him to give the ransom to the kidnappers. The millionaire's aide is Phillip Seymour Hoffman, who plays a sycophantic named Brandt. Hoffman is the third most enjoyable character in the film, with his forced laugh and yes-man lines.

The simple ransom goes horribly wrong and the plot gets ever more complex as more characters are added. This one of a few comedies that warrants multiple viewings just to understand it. There are enough quotable lines to be entertaining upon first watch but you have to see it again to discern the genius of the plot turns.

The dream sequences take away from the film as they are too long and don't really move the movie forward or even introduce a side-plot. Still, the film is one of the best Coen films (not as great as Fargo, but what is?) and it remains a cult classic and one of the best comedies ever made.

The thing about movies made by the Coen Brothers is that I either love them (Fargo) or they leave me flat (The Big Lebowski). There is a thin line between comic and tragic, and here the lead characters never find it. As played by Jeff Bridges and John Goodman, two dumber Polacks have never graced the silver screen. Yet, there is nothing Polish or Polish-American about these losers---"The Dude" Lebowski and Walter Sobchak-except their names, and "Sobchak" is a very un-Polish spelling. There are a couple of assumptions that you have to make to laugh at the jokes in this 1998 film. One is that Polish surnames are innately funny and you should laugh when you hear one, especially when it is associated with intelligent thought or combined with an American given name ("Bunny Lebowski"). The only time you hear the word "Polish" in the movie is when The Dude explains to Sobchak that he is "not even Jewish": "You're f---ing Polish-Catholic." So why see this film? Because it raises a lot of questions, such as: What's so funny about stupidity? Why does John Goodman seem to be doing an imitation of Roseanne Barr? Would this have worked better as a cartoon? Why is "Lebowski" considered a "jerk-off name"? Another reason is to watch Julianne Moore deliver another bizarre but intriguing performance. As Maude Lebowski, she leads The Dude, a burned-out hippie, into the only one of his lines that made me laugh out loud by asking him post-coitally what he does for recreation. As if it's the first time he's ever been asked, he thinks for a second, then replies, "Go bowling, drive around, and the occasional acid flashback."

review_title: Neither the best nor the worst.....
review_detailed_main: Excuse me all of you who loved this movie....I really don't understand what the hype is all about....... I'm sorry but.....allow me pinpoint some aspects.....Is the movie funny? Yeah, a little... it shows a lot of acid humor and sarcasm , which by the way I love....Otherwise, the movie lacks of consistency. or let me say, a spinal cord...it has great specific moments of excellence....although is not enough for pasting all of them into a unique brightness piece..... The storyline in general is poor...in my opinion.....sometimes I felt as if the movie has just stopped..... Look Burn after reading for instance.....it's the most great movie of Coen brothers.....I loved it!!! The main characters are great in The big Lebowski despite of their just passable interaction ....highlighting Jesus, who was by far my favorite character...appealing, flashy, arrogant and clueless at the same time... On the background I've enjoyed the subject, specially the greed, which is continuously at our side all the time.... live, and see how petty and greedy people are.... Bottom line, if you are looking for a deep and dense experience under Coen's label, this is not the right movie, try No place for old country, Fargo or mainly Burn after reading.

I recommended this movie to a friend of mine and he asked me what kind of movie it was. I answered; "it's the best movie ever made" "Why?" he asked and I answered; "why not?" Seriously, why not? It has the most amazing characters, you can pick your favorite sure, but non of them sucks, and they are all played brilliantly. It has the most amazing dialogs, everything that is said in this movie is just so brilliant, if you don't agree, then, that's just, like, your opinion, man. It has the most amazing story, it's both strange and interesting, and the way it's told keeps your eyes on the screen the whole time. I've probably seen this movie about 20 times now, and I enjoy it every time, every god damn time it's brilliant and mind-blowing and funny, and enjoyable and etc. So I ask again, why is it not the best movie ever made? why, the hell, is The big Lebowsky, not the best, movie, ever, made?

There's not much to say about this movie. I enjoyed it, of course not as much as i would enjoy a movie that I myself rated 8 or higher, but this was indeed a good movie. The actors were all on the same line, and what i liked the most about this film is the film setting and the mood that movie puts you in, especially with the astonishing soundtracks that got me in the movie from the start; the only reason why this movie isn't highly rated is because it's slow paced many times, which is not something that I enjoy. But after all this is a perfect movie you can watch on a Sunday afternoon with friends and that's exactly what I did. Maybe don't watch this with your family, you know, swear words.

Text: I will not say much about this thing, but this is a movie with the most idiot brainless characters and the most silly meaningless dialogues i've ever seen in my life. That's all i can say about it, just a lousy thing no more. This movie was made in the nineties, the decade with the most wonderful movies ever made and yet there are some people still like it!!!! Ok maybe i came from another planet, but again this movie is just a piece of Nothing but bull@#*# and a completely waste of time.

review_title: it's so good to watch this after so long
review_detailed_main:
this thought provoking, hallucinated, greatly written comedy is so funny you will hold your guts. I have watched it perhaps 7 times, and it still is not only entertaining but really funny and just great time to spend watching a movie.

Jeff bridges at his best ever, i think, it is so funny this man the dude should be everyone's hero. the movie is also about peace in his own intrinsically and curiously unusual way. Looking at it after now 10 years after it was made is not only still a great laugh, but also inspiring. It's good now and then to get back in to rock and roll. I think the movie tackles important questions about life, in an intensely comical and intelligent way. I live in Europe and it might just be that people who are not so familiar with the American culture would not be able to catch the great humor, but I feel blessed to be able to understand the hero that the dude is playing. i truly wish i was like him.

review_title: Unique and brilliant in its own way

review_detailed_main: The style of noir, crossed with the era of the 60s and the Twilight Zone against the backdrop of the 90s, gave rise to the effect, on the one hand, of the multi-layered characters and interpretations, and on the other hand, accessibility for understanding by the ordinary viewer, and, consequently, recognition of themselves in the characters. And in fact, people like Dude, Walter and Donnie can often be found in various segments of the population in any country, whether it be the States or Russia. Infantile, psychotic, notorious and at the same time strangely charming inhabitants of the Coen universe suddenly gained a wide audience. And the plot, which in fact is not in the film at all, has gained vitality, as if in front of the viewer his own, albeit pretty stoned, everyday life.

review_title: Most unique, most funny comedy I've seen
review_detailed_main:
Possibly the funniest movie I've ever seen. Perfect character development and acting combined with an out-there but flawlessly-interwoven series of plots are the perfect combination for laughs. I can't get enough of this movie, and neither will you.

This story follows three bowling buddies- Lebowski aka "The Dude" (Jeff Bridges), an aging burnout hippie with a carefree, laidback manner; Walter (John Goodman), a large Vietnam War veteran who approaches his daily life and philosophy as if he were still at war; and Donnie (Steve Buschemi), a dimwit follower placed mostly for comic relief. A case of mistaken identity gets the three caught up in the aftermath of a kidnapping, and watching their antics as they try to sort their way through the situation is as funny a thing as I've seen.

I think the beauty in this movie is that there don't have to be any jokes or actual attempts to be funny to produce a laugh. The characters, just by being themselves, make the movie funny. Every scene where they're in the bowling alley talking to each other- there's no joke or attempt at humor, just a burnout, a dimwit, and a gun toter with post-traumatic stress disorder sitting there talking for five minutes, and I die laughing. Heck, there doesn't even have to be dialog! The scene where Lebowski is driving down the road smoking a roach- two minutes go by from start to end without an intelligible word of dialog, and I must have laughed 3 times. Or his reaction to being forced in the limo ("Watch out, there's a beverage here!"). He was being serious, and that by itself made it funny. Just by being themselves, the characters are funny and hence the movie is funny. Well, that and a few well-placed dream sequences!

If you haven't seen this movie, drop what you're doing and run to the video store. You are in for a treat.

I think that the film took quite a while for the jokes to start, with the first 30 minutes [ish] focussing on setting the scenen for the rest of the film. Having said that, however, there are some hilarious moments. Overall a pretty good watch. One major thing i did disagree with though is when Jeff Bridges said "I hate the f***ing Eagles" - the eagles rule. Also, why did Steve Buscemi [Donny] have to die?

review_title: Lots of moving parts & information will come to light...........
review_detailed_main: When you set out to relax and forget about your mostly miserable life,this is the type of entertainment you should seek. The characters are superbly portrayed & the story written perfectly for them. So many great things I could say, but I don't really like typing soooo, just watch the masterpiece and rate it 10 stars here when your surfing the web looking for ,for, nothing. Remember, tune in-turn on-drop out-culture is not your friend and its just a ride..........

review_title: I had expected more from the Coen brothers...
review_detailed_main: Two of my favorite movies are Raising Arizona and The Hudsucker Proxy, and Fargo was pretty good too. I expected a lot from this movie but was somewhat disapointed. The plot was harder to follow than their other movies, and after seeing it twice it still seems kinda stupid. There were too many groups working against and with each other to really pull the end together smoothly. I think there was a lot of great acting, but it didn't really help the movie. But I think they are coming out with a new movie soon, so maybe it will turn out better...

This film is totally unique in a world of sequels, copy-cat and cookie-cutter films. This movie is absolutely hilarious with an immensely talented ensemble cast and sharp Coen brothers writing. It's one of those films that gets better with each viewing because you notice more detail and nuance. Jeff Bridges was made for this role. John Goodman proves his genius. The bit players are all perfect. This film turns the "private eye noir" genre on it's head and into a truly enjoyable and unpredictable twister game.

Along with "Miller's Crossing" it's one of the Coen Brothers movies that has the dialogue and writing to stand among the classics like "Casablanca".

In this eccentric comedy/crime film by the Coen brothers, they created an outstanding movie. The actors/actress in the film was perfectly unified in a great way that audience could build a vision of the plot. If you can handle the graphic dialogue used and suggestive behavior this is the right movie for you.

The theme of the film is Jeff "Dude"Lebowski (Jeff Bridges) discovers he is a victim of mistaken identity. Thugs were sent to his home by Jackie Treehorn (Ben Gazzara) to recover a debit; Big Lebowski's (The Millionaire) wife owes him. Before the thugs realize they have the wrong Lebowski and that he's the "Dude" they urinate of his rug; leaving Dude in disgust. Dude pays BigLebowski (David Huddleston) a visit to be compensated for his rug being destroyed. Big Lebowski filled with arrogance; felt he was there looking for a hand out. Dude felt the conversation wasn't getting anywhere and decided he would take a rug from Lebowski home to be even.

When Bunny (Tara Reid) disappears (Lebowski's wife); Big Lebowski contacts Dude making him an offer to be the bagman. The only thing Dude has to do is deliver the ransom money for Bunny. Dude brings Walter (John Goodman) along to make the drop. When the drop goes to pieces it creates a ricochet of others trying to reclaim the ransom money. While home listening to the soothing sounds of the bowling pins being knocked down, he discovers 3 people standing over him. They knocked him out and he begins to hallucinate; the lighting becomes dark with bright lights in the sky as he floats in sky. During the hallucination Dude see the rug he confiscated from Big Lebowski's. He is woken once his bowling ball drops him back to the surface.

After coming back to reality, Dude is greeted by a women flying through the air on a stripe line in the nude, Maude Lebowski (Julianne Moore). Dude and Maude forms a relationship. Dude without realizing has been sized up to be a sperm donor of her child. Dude experienced many encounters because he was trying to clear his identity. After having sex with Maude and enjoy a marijuana joint, at that moment Dude realized the reasoning behind the mistaken identity fiasco. In conclusion, as a motif in the film "Dude" was the main character's name; however, it was used as a common word of expression during dialogue. Dude was able to regain his identity and continued being the old lazy, laid back, unemployed, and bowler from Southern California.

review_title: Dummest Damn Movie I Think I've Ever Watched
Your revolution is over Mr. Lebowski!
review_detailed_main:
I've lost count of how many times I've seen this film and each time it seems to get better and better. Yet, the first time I saw this film I didn't think it was a great movie since I didn't realize the true greatness of it (in fact, I think no one did). This is because the movie is not about the plot or about the message. This movie is great because of its characters, dialogue and aesthetics, things that are most appreciated with successive viewings. It's the little details that will make this your favourite comedy of all time.

Jeff Bridges, John Goodman and Steve Buscemi are outstanding as the three bowling buddies and excellently supported by Philip Seymour Hoffman and Julianne Moore. In fact I think most would agree that Jeff Bridges and especially John Goodman gave award-winning performances. The dialogue is truly amazing. I mean how many movies are bestowed with so many memorable lines as this one? It is also truly unique. For a good-hearted and laid-back sort of film, to contain that many and different subtle references to cultural idiosyncrasies really says something. Finally, and I think this is what gives the movie defining cult status, it's the aesthetics. You can tell the effort made by directors and actors alike in carefully constructing each character. Each character has been embedded with a particular style and ethos which explain their way of going about things. Each character is both cause and effect of different generational prototypes mingling with each other in that psychedelic fauna that is The Big Lebowski.

review_title: The Dude just wants his rug back.
review_detailed_main:
From those that I've seen, every one of the Coen Brothers' movies has that peculiar charm; offbeat characters, an odd sense of humor, what-have-you. And then there's "The Big Lebowski", a different beast entirely. Get a load of this thing: it's a mystery yarn set against the backdrop of a bowling tournament, with more F-words than a whorehouse, a host of whacked-out characters and the protagonists are a stoner and his crazy Vietnam veteran buddy. It's also one of the most quotable movies ever produced. The magic is in the dialogue.

But it's one of my all-time favorite movies because of the two leads. John Goodman seems to exist solely to keep Jeff Bridges in a state of perpetual exasperation, and their bickering never fails to send me into a fit of giggles.

Also, if I can get Sam Elliott to narrate my life story, I'd call that a big bucket of win.

10/10

review_title: White Russian laced with hash and horse
The one reason to drink white russians
review_detailed_main:
The absurdity, the coolness, and the essence of just being are present in a cocktail of so like the brothers Coen.

At first I didn't want to go to see this movie as I am not into "lazy time wasting slackers" or bowling. I know now that I have truly underestimated the importance of bowling, and that God is in the details.

review_title: It is so good that i cant describe how good it really is.

review_detailed_main: This movie was good but by no means a master piece. The plot tried a bit to hard to be cleaver and the humor wasn't the best. The acting was good by all involved with the exception of Julian Moore who's acting was sub par. Worth a watch but don't go in expecting too much. I saw this in 2017 so maybe at the time the movie was better and doesn't hold up to more modern takes on similar story.

This film is flawless. Everything about it is just awesome. The jokes, the characters ( especially the characters ) and much more. The plot is very well done, basically the dominio affect cranked to eleven. Basically this is a absolute must watch for anyone who knows anything about movies. Watch this movie because it is so good.

Some parts are funny, but the script isn't that much.

Worth watching if you have nothing more to watch, but some parts the "comedy" and the story just seems that the writter is forcing something to "be funny" or to be clever. It's not organic.

For sure I feel it's overrated, I heard about it in a lot of places, but maybe since I'm not american, I didn't get some inside jokes or special references.

review_title: A surefire comedy, this film is pure genius
review_detailed_main:
The Big Lebowski is a brilliant comedy, but it also has a very unique plot. If you liked Fargo, you might also like this because it involves a simple plot, but involves several incidents that add to the story and make it funnier as it goes.

There are several unique characters like the artist played by Julianne Moore, the Hispanic bowler named Jesus played by John Turturro, and one of my favorite characters is the boisterous bowler named Walter, who is played by John Goodman. The story is centered around a lowlife bowler named Jeff Lebowski, or 'the dude' as everyone calls him. One day his house is broken into and his beloved carpet is soiled, all because he was mistaken for a multimillionaire with the same last name as him. He tries to get help from the Big Lebowski, but doesn't get anything, until the big Lebowki needs help and the Dude and his bowling buddies decide to assist him. The result is an entertaining and wickedly hilarious trip to regaining the dude's prized possession.

The plot is simple at first, until it gets more complex. The film requires more viewings to appreciate everything, but there is still plenty to like the first time you see it, such as the humor, the camera angle shown through the finger hole of a bowling ball, and the clever dream sequences. See this film once to be entertained, but see it several other times to realize the genius that was involved in it.

review_title: this is really fun... just this!
review_detailed_main: This movie is really good but that's really confusable in some parts and drive me crazy about that... In all I can just say this movie has worth to watch...so don't waste the time,watch it as soon as possible!

review_title: Does not age well AT ALL!
review_detailed_main: I saw this movie when it first came out and thought it was hip, funny, original, quirky and cool, as did so many of the gushing reviewers who have commented already.
