I missed The Big Lebowski when it was at theaters, and after reading all the hoopla and praise foisted in its direction, had to rent it and finally see it.

Big mistake.

As with Pulp Fiction, I just don't see what the hype is about. The humor is sparse as far as I'm concerned, with John Goodman's character being the only redeeming part of the entire movie.

Yeah, I paid attention. And I watched it twice. It didn't help.

Some people have raved over the joke that the main character's rug "Really tied the room together". If that is what passes for great humor, well count me out.

review_title: one of the funniest movies ever
review_detailed_main: This is one of the funniest movies I have ever seen and i never get bored of watching it again and again.The great acting between the three main characters, Goodman, Bridges and Buscemi,is 100% pure fun to watch. Even if Buscemi does not say that much he gives his part a memorable performance.All the other actors who have small parts are hilarious. Take Turturro for example who plays a latino bowling player named Jesus with such perfect acting so I can´t help laughing.So if you´re looking for a very twisted and well played comedy this is the one to see. This picture will make you feel really good.Don´t miss the burial scene.

review_title: F*ck it Dude, let's go bowling.
review_detailed_main:
What to say about this film that hasn't already been guessed at?? The story comes in and out of a period in Jeffrey Lebowski's (The Dude) life and shows the ease with which he gets himself into ridiculous situations.

I gave this film 10 out of 10 (one of only 3 films to score this out of about 600 I've rated - take note all you people out there giving Daredevil etc 10 points!)

The editing is superb, the lighting and use of colours is unlike anything I've ever seen. Examples include the darkness which falls at the scene of a disasterous event outside the bowling alley in the second half. Another is the jump cut to an exploding firework used when The Dude is punched whilst lying on his new rug. The trails of light from the firework then morph seamlessly into an aeriel view of the lights on the streets of LA at night. Amazing stuff.

Visuals are great, but when not backed up with equally good dialogue you can end up with a George Lucas movie. The dialogue in this film is at times nothing short of astonishing. John Goodman's character, Walter, is a Vietnam veteran with excellent vocabulary, historical awareness, philosophical ability; all shot through with tirades of foul language. He is both hilarious and thought provoking, much like the film as a whole.

With a supporting cast of John Turturro, Julianne Moore, Steve Buscemi, David Huddleston, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Peter Stormare and Tara Reid; the movie shimmers with comic timing and great acting.

It's one of the best. Easily said I know, but in this case it's true.

I honestly don't understand why anyone would want to see this movie. It manages to be simultaneously obnoxious, ridiculously stupid, and incredibly, mind-numbingly boring all at the same time. If one is fond of toilet humor and a seemingly endless stream of swear words coming out of the actors' mouths then I suppose this movie might be appealing, but I don't see the attraction. The plot of the movie is virtually nonexistent, and the dialogue is horrendous, mostly consisting of the f-word. By far the most obnoxious character is Walter, played by John Goodman, whose incessant uttering of the phrase "Am I wrong?" began grating on my nerves within the first twenty minutes. This movie is, while perhaps not the worst movie I've ever seen, definitely near the bottom of the barrel.

review_title: A Film that really ties the room together

review_detailed_main:
The Big Lebowski is one of the very few comedies that actually gets better every time you watch it. The characters are some of the best to ever be created in movie making history: The Dude, Walter, Donny, Jesus Quintana, and the Nihilists. There are about (total) 20 slow minutes in the movie, and the rest of it is absolutely hilarious. John Goodman's performance as Walter is Oscar material, and definitely my favorite character of any movie I've ever seen, from giving his choice words to Donny to relating just about everything that happens to Vietnam. The conversations at the bowling alley are classics. In 1998, I saw two of the best comedies I've ever seen: There's Something About Mary, and The Big Lebowski, and The Big Lebowski wins hands down. I'll just leave you with this:

Walter: (speaking about Quintana) He spent 6 months in Chino for exposing himself to an 8 year old. When he moved to Hollywood he had to go door to door and tell his neighbors he was a paedorast.

Donny: What's a paedorast, Walter?

Walter: Shut the f*** up Donny.

Nothing else comes to mind when I hear somewone mention "The Big Lebowski". It is simply the best movie I have ever seen! The more stupid and outrageous it gets, the more hilarious it becomes. This movie includes everything that an excellent movie calls for; awesome casting job (Jeff Bridges, John Goodman, Sam Elliot, Steve Buscemi, etc), humor nothing can deliver, bowling, some lazy guy named Dude, to some "self-described" Nihilists. The Coen Brothers have once again made movies more enjoyable. I highly recommend this flick for anyone who needs a good laugh.

review_title: A little far out of left field but nonetheless solid, gripping tale.
review_detailed_main: This movie has a big personality, and I could have given it a 10, but I felt that a 9 was more appropriate. This is basically a post-modern tale that anyone growing up in the 90's will understand. Everyone should find this entertaining, especially on re-runs on all the networks. It requires attention span as the story is rather complicated. It also has a great number of characters to introduce. But the filmmakers do it so well that it doesn't lose any points. I didn't give it a 10 because it is so outlandish and over-the-top that even the most gullible will want to walk away from it at times. There is a character, played by John Turturro, who is a registered sex offender, who plays bowling alongside the three main characters in league bowling, and they felt the need to do a cut-scene to tell his story, even though he is only in one scene. Also, there is the guy who is a stage actor, who wants the Dude to go to his performance, and the dude nearly forgets - this character has nothing at all to do with this movie, so the scenes changed about every 2 minutes!!! Also, John Goodman's character getting away with threatening to shoot someone in public, and the cops show up and somehow miss him!! Way too over-the-top. It felt at times like a pornographic display of garishness.

review_title: Very intelligent on a dumb sort of way!!!
review_detailed_main:
This movie's just great! Jeff Bridges was brilliant and he definitely deserved an Oscar for The Dude! I'm usually a fan of Coen Brother's ever since they made their first movie, Blood Simple, and they haven't disappointed since! Sure they've made a couple of average movies but never a bad movie! Not so far, at least!

John Goodman was also great if not the funniest character in this movie! His character is just brilliant! A guy that turned Jewish since he's married his wife who left him, always talking about Vietnam and about how he saw his friends with their faces in the mud even when they're talking about potatoes for instance, and so on... and so on... I can't find any mistakes in this film except that i would have really loved to see a bit more of Steve Buscemi!

The script and the directing are also great as expected from Coen Brothers. Violence is just in line. Not overdone and not underdone. And the music is just brilliant!!!!

This is a well packed, very well written mix of black comedy and a thriller that's way too intelligent to be dumb and way too dumb to be intelligent! A masterpiece!!!

I couldn't follow any of the plot because all it seemed to have in it are these two men swearing. I don't mind the swearing when it serves a purpose, but this movie was ridiculous. It seemed to me that every other word was the "F" word. If you can get past the language, you might be able to tell if there is a story to it.

review_title: One of the most hilarious movies I've ever seen
Mix Yourself a White Russian and Bask in Lebowski's Absurdity
review_detailed_main:
What a ludicrous story. Absolutely bizarre in every way, and all the better for it. It was an absolute farce and there no sense or logic to much of it. All of this makes it very hard not to love The Big Lebowski.

The characters were so rich and eccentric that I really didn't know what was going to happen or why it was going to happen. The Coen's are experts in keeping you on your toes during a film. Just when you think things are going to zig the plot goes right ahead and zags. I absolutely love this style of story, and if you are a fan of the Coen's other work, particularly Fargo, this will be right up your street due to the similar levels of farce and buffoonery.

Bridges and Goodman were electric, with such good oddball chemistry between them. The sharp script was excellently delivered by both, handling comedy and drama equally well. Buscemi was a fantastic support as expected but the real standout aside from Bridges and Goodman was Julianne Moore. She was an absolute scene stealer whenever she was on screen, adding another great oddball character to the mix. Philip Seymour Hoffman as well! The list goes on, but suffice to say the cast was eclectic and excellent.

The Big Lebowski is wildly entertaining, although I must say I never really found it hilarious. Sure it was funny in parts, and there were laughs to be had, but it was never laugh out loud funny for me. Maybe some of the humour didn't age so well I'm not sure, for example the character of Jesus. Still funny but not as hilarious as it perhaps was 20 years ago. The Coen's deal more in black comedy and farce anyway, so I found myself smirking a sufficient amount which is a good sign.

As you'd expect from the Coen's the direction was pretty slick. Arty, surreal, and clean in equal measure. To top it all off there was a pretty popping soundtrack.

The Big Lebowski is a hoot! Probably one of the greatest collection of odd characters and the most absurd of plots combine to make a triumphant piece of cinema.

review_title: The rug that ties the room together!
review_detailed_main:
'THE BIG LEBOWSKI' was directed by Joel and Ethan Coen, and stars Jeff Bridges, John Goodman and Julian Moore. When 'The Dude'(Jeff Bridges) is mistaken for Jeffrey Lebowski(David Huddleston), his life becomes a lot more complicated than before.

Word of Advice: watch this movie while intoxicated. I watched it while sober and still enjoyed it immensely but I guarantee that watching this movie while off your head will improve it. That said, this is a very enjoyable comedy. Jeff Bridges shines bright as 'The Dude' with an excellent cast, including John Goodman and Phillip Seymour Hoffman, also providing great performances and being the potatoes to this meat and potato pie. The comedy is pretty good and I'll definitely say that more jokes hit than they do fail. That said, I won't say that many jokes in this movie are hysterically funny; I chuckled a lot but I only full on laughed out loud maybe 2 or 3 times. That isn't a massive gripe but it's something I though I should mention.

My main gripe with this movie is that being intoxicated is probably the best way to see it, and that is not a major gripe at all. The story is pretty basic but works well for what it is attempting to do. Despite this, they set up a lot of character and story arcs that go NOWHERE which was really annoying. That is my second major flaw with this movie. It sets up interesting characters like Jesus and even Donnie but then ignores them or even completely forgets them for the majority of the plot. I would rather the characters not be in the movie, than have them in it for only a minuscule amount of time. The ending(which I love by the way) is very open and allows a lot more possibilities for sequels where they could have explored these characters more and gave them more depth instead of cramming them all into this one movie.

Even with these flaws, the movie is very damn enjoyable. Its incredible, colourful, imaginative characters really drive the movie and they are what makes this movie shine. That is why I wanted more time going to some of the supporting roles. A lot of effort was clearly put into these characters and I wish they got more screen time to bloom.

It's a very technically proficient movie; the cinematography is pretty good. The set and costume design is great. I have no real flaws with this movie as far as sets and camera-work goes. Maybe a few changes to character and set design but I can't say it was anything that really hindered my enjoyment.

All in all, this movie is very enjoyable sober(and I imagine even more so while on something) therefor I do recommend this movie to anyone, so long as you're prepared to possibly have a breakdown during a few sequences of this movie. It's a very enjoyable movie, and I'll rate it 8 rugs out of 10.

Probably one of the best comedies ever. Jeff Bridges is so underrated. "The Dude" in my book is one of the best heros in movie history. If you like Fargo more than this movie, you're braindead. This film rocks!

Arguably one of the funniest movies of all time. This film had it all lots of laughs, great acting, and the hero went by the name of The Dude. The movie is hilarious without a doubt the Coen brothers best work. i hope they can do another project like this sometime soon.

review_title: Quite possibly the greatest movie of all time
review_detailed_main:
Let me say first off that I HATED this movie the first time I walked out of it. I did however watch it again over the years and I have to think it was just my age at the time (I was 19) and now being the ripe old age of 32 I have to say I might enjoy this for repeat viewings more than anything else.

So, what makes this movie great?

First off, it has one of the single best scripts I have ever seen. It is funny, weird and incredibly quotable. The characters are well drawn and so odd that you can't help but love them. The Coen brothers have made some very good movies but nothing compares to the utter genius displayed here.

The Big Lebowski exists on the plain of earth that we just don't inhabit. In this film LA is a magical place that walks the along edge of lunacy. A bit mythological and just subversive to keep us coming back again and again for a great movie that never loses it's sparkle.

The Dude Abides...

review_title: Possibly the greatest comedy ever. A true gem.
review_detailed_main:
As far as I'm concerned this is easily the very best movie the incredible Coen brothers have made to date. Comedy is one of the most difficult, demanding genres around, and in order for it to work it must be made with a professionalism that exceeds all imagination. Now that's one of the many great things about "The Big Lebowski". Everything in this movie is sheer genius, every detail is right, and the timing is perfect, but it feels so laidback you hardly notice the brilliance and skill.

What else can I say ? The Dude is just about the coolest main character you can possibly imagine, and he's surrounded by a hilarious troupe of supporting characters that make this film a truly worthwile event. Walter Sobchak, Donnie, the three nihilists, the Jesus, Maude, Jackie Treehorn, Brandt, Knox Harrington ... they're all hysterically funny. Same goes for the nonsensical situations The Dude gets into. The first appereance of the Jesus, the farret scene, the toilet scene ("Where's the money Lebowski ?"), the confrontation on the parking lot, the money handover, the beach scene, and so many more wonderful moments - I'll kick myself for not mentioning them later... they can make anyone with a sense of humour howl with laughter, again and again and again.

The cast is tremendous: Jeff Bridges is in my opinion one of the best American actors around and as The Dude, he finally got the chance to show what a remarkable comedian he really is. John Goodman, Steve Buscemi, John Turturro, Julianne Moore, Philip Seymour Hoffman... each and every one of them gives a new meaning to the word "delicious".

In short, this movie is such a feast of wonderful dialogues, hilarious characters and unbelievably funny scenes it's already a true classic. The Dude abides, man, The Dude abides...

Just saw this movie for the first time. It was absolutely rubbish. I litteraly laughed 1 time. Great names and great reviews so i give it a chance.

Don't waste your time. Don't believe the reviews. I never fell asleep while i'm watching a movie. With these movie my eyes was starting to burn. Just because it was do damn boring.

A lot of swear words and offended language and none comedy. 2 hours long it feels like they do the same thing over and over again. That was the longest 2 hours in my entire life.

This has to be the greatest movie of all time.... I'll say it again....You told Brandt on the phone, he told me. Yes Yes.... The bums will always lose.... Shut the F**k up Donnie! Classic unforgettable line after line... A work of Art.... How can Clerks be above this in the Ratings? This is at 228 and dropping...Come on people... The Coen Brothers are 2 of the most intelligent writers and directors in the history of Film....Period... Incredible....the film would have been flawless if it was not for the Flying with the Bowling ball trip thing

and the other dancing scene. David Huddleston was perfect as the Other Jeff Lebowski... He should have won something for that role...

When a director does such a masterpiece as "Fargo", it's very unlikely that he will repeat the same level of excellence in his next film. With "The Big Lebowski", the Coen brothers not only did a good movie, but a truly excellent comedy. I was laughing so hard when I saw this movie that I almost cried. I have seen it three times now and the impact is always huge, it's hilarious. It's also smart, full of quotable lines and remarks, and gripping to the very end... in fact I was enjoying it so much that I didn't want it to end! The characters are memorable, and all the actors do a magnificent job, but John Goodman steals the movie, to me it's his best film ever. A must see!

review_title: Among The Greatest of American Comedies
review_detailed_main:
To me, the three funniest American movies ever made are A NIGHT AT THE OPERA, YOUNG FRANKENSTEIN, and THE BIG LEBOWSKI.

It's really interesting to notice the similarities between the three movies. YOUNG FRANKENSTEIN is a spoof of classic horror movies from the thirties. THE BIG LEBOWSKI is a spoof of classic detective movies from the thirties and forties. Both movies totally capture the feel of the original genre and feel authentic even when being deliberately funny. The Dude is a lot like the Monster, a slow and clumsy but basically good-hearted character who spends most of the movie stumbling around not quite knowing what is going on, while the hysterical characters all around him create bizarre complications.

Also, notice that both YOUNG FRANKENSTEIN and THE BIG LEBOWSKI feature show-stopping musical numbers, each of which come out of nowhere and feature the rumpled, clumsy main character suddenly recast as a dapper song and dance man. "Puttin' On the Ritz" and "Just Stopped In (To See What Condition My Condition Is In") are both numbers that take an already successful comedy and push it into the realm of a total classic.

A lot of the humor in THE BIG LEBOWSKI parallels the humor of A NIGHT AT THE OPERA. In both movies, wealthy society people attempt to boss around deadbeats and eccentrics, who soon turn the tables and create all kinds of mischief. Maude Lebowski, with her artistic tastes, cheerful snobbery, and fundamentally gullible nature, is a perfect update of the well-to-do women Margaret Dumont always played in the Marx Brothers classic comedies. The difference is that Maude is never, ever reduced to the role of a simple straight man (or woman.) Indeed, her wit is often a lot sharper than the Dude's. ("The dialog is inane, and the plot ludicrous . . . of course you can imagine where it goes from here." "He fixes the cable?" "Don't be fatuous, Jeffrey.")

This brings up the final point I want to make about THE BIG LEBOWSKI. There are no straight men. There are no small parts. Every single character is funny and the effect is dazzling. Whereas Groucho has to be the funniest character in every scene, the Dude himself is often allowed to step back and allow the weirdness of others to shine. This is what makes THE BIG LEBOWSKI a unique comedy masterpiece.

So what keeps this movie from being a perfect ten? The ending is a little anti-climactic, and the death of a major character dampens the impact. Also the use of the cowboy character in the bowling alley (and as a narrator) struck me as being an annoying distraction.

Review: 'The Big Lebowski' 'The Big Lebowski' by the Coen brothers is a great film because of its great characters. The cast includes Jeff Bridges, John Goodman, Julianne Moore, John Turturro and many more. 'The Big Lebowski' released in 1998 is a quirky crime comedy about an unemployed slacker from L.A who is drawn into a world of kidnapping after being mistaken for a washed up millionaire of the same name. To summarize it 'The Big Lebowski' is about 'The Dude' a slacker and a keen bowler, when two enforcers show up at his house demanding money, having mistook him for a millionaire with the same name and urinating on his carpet, he is plunged into a world of deceit, kidnapping and much more in the pursuit to be compensated for his ruined carpet. A summary of the plot does not do this film justice. The character of 'The Dude' is brought to life by the outstanding performance of Jeff Bridges. The dude has so many hilarious quotes and back and forths with his counterpart 'Walter' played by John Goodman. Jeff Bridges seamlessly plays 'The Dude' with laid back perfection. I was disappointed though with Steve Buscemi's character 'Donny' having very few lines in the film although whenever he does talk he is usually told to shut up which can be quite funny. Another film by the Coen brothers called 'Fargo' has Steve Buscemi in a much bigger role than in this one and he is excellent in 'Fargo'. I would have preferred if he was given a bigger role like in 'Fargo'. John Turturro has a hilarious performance as 'Jesus' but little screen time. During the film's spectacular dream sequences are used with great effect. The soundtrack for the film is very good too. In conclusion 'The Big Lebowski' is more about the characters than the plot. I would recommend this film too everyone and I would give it a 9/10. It is my favourite Coen brothers' film and my favourite film with Jeff Bridges in it that I have seen.

Great movie. Coen Brothers and Roger Deakins how bad can it be .Take look at this , this movie has it's own religion called Dudeism.It derives from The Dude , the main character of the movie.The thing that made this movie irreplaceable is his responses to the incidents that happen to rather than the movies plot.Doubtlessly the most beloved character in this movie is 'The Dude' but we shouldn't forger Walter too.He is the guy that makes you laugh every single second as you watch. This movie also includes criticism about Vietnam war and other political cases that makes this masterpiece even better.If you really understand the characters and watch this movie with analyzing them without looking other components I have no doubt that you are gonna really enjoy this movie.And surely you're gonna envy the lifestyle of the dude. Moreover Jeff Bridges is definitely the best actor for playing The Dude. If you watched it and didn't like it . Yeah ,well, that's just, like, your opinion, man.

I love the Cohen Brothers. I've seen most of their movies way more than once. This one.. barely made it through once.

All the characters were horrible! I wanted to reach into the movie and clunk "The Dude" in the head. John Goodman's character was unspeakably rude and stupid and offensive. What a waste of Steve Buschemi! The only part that was amusing was Julianna Moore's character-- mostly because she was doing a great impression of Katherine Hepburn. Now that I think of it, the dream sequences were surreal enough to be interesting, especially the bit with a POV of the inside of a bowling ball!

My friend who recommended it replied to my objections by saying, "Oh, maybe I forgot to mention that this is a movie best watched stoned." Yeah... maybe. Do yourself a favor. Skip this one and watch Miller's Crossing again!

review_title: Watch out Farrellys, Coen Brothers do a comedy funnier & smarter
review_detailed_main:
The Big Lebowski is about a man with balls, THE DUDE. It wasn't his fault someone urinated on his rug, but thats only the beginning of this laugh out loud comedy from the people who brought you FARGO.

The Coen Brothers got so much critical acclaim for their previous film, that they decided to mix it up here. And they did, some critics loved it, some hated it, after seeing Fargo I have to admit it wasn't what I expected. But they roll enough solid laughs and camera tricks to satisfy even the most vengeful critic (get over it, they wanted to do a comedy, and they did it better then most).

Scoring a perfect 300 is THE DUDE. He is the guy you wish you could be if you had the guts to throw all responsibility behind you and enjoy life not caring what people think of you or what you do. The Dude never was shown rolling a bowling ball during the movie despite most of it taking place during a bowling match involving him.

And also scoring a perfect 300 (may-be he won't shoot me) is Walter played by John Goodman. Never better or louder, Goodman plays a Volcanic Vietnam Vet, who shouts paranoid logic and profanity.

Steve Buscemi may have had a good score but every time he tried to talk Walter told him to shut the ____ up, So I give him a 250. Hey what can I say, he played the "loser in the group" better than most.

And last but not least, a 200 to John Turturro who played a Hispanic pedophile bowling champ named Jesus.

Pete's Movie Rating (out of 10): 9

Dead funny, hilarious, intelligent and absolutely original. The acting (especially John Goodman) is first rate and the Coen brothers seem to have the time of their life. No deeper thoughts here, just entertainment for a demanding audience.

review_title: A Quirky and Absurd Cult Classic
review_detailed_main:
"The Big Lebowski" (1998), directed by the Coen brothers, is a cult classic that combines comedy, absurdity, and philosophical depth. The film follows the story of Jeffrey "The Dude" Lebowski (Jeff Bridges), a laid-back, bowling-obsessed man who gets caught up in a bizarre case of mistaken identity.

Plot The Dude is mistaken for a wealthy man with the same name, Jeffrey Lebowski, by two thugs who come to his house looking for a debt. They trash his home and urinate on his rug, leading The Dude to seek revenge and a new rug. Along the way, he meets a colorful cast of characters, including his best friend Walter Sobchak (John Goodman), a volatile and violent man, and Maude Lebowski (Julianne Moore), a wealthy woman who becomes his unlikely ally.

Performances Jeff Bridges delivers a masterful performance as The Dude, capturing the character's laid-back attitude and philosophical nature. John Goodman shines as Walter, adding a comedic element with his intense and often violent demeanor. Julianne Moore's Maude adds depth and complexity to her character, making her a memorable part of the film.

Atmosphere and Visuals The film boasts a quirky and absurd atmosphere, with the Coen brothers' signature use of dream sequences and over-the-top humor. The imagery is often colorful and imaginative, creating a sense of whimsy and absurdity. The cinematography is fast-paced and often slapstick, adding to the film's comedic impact.

Conclusion "The Big Lebowski" is a must-see for fans of smart comedy. The film's blend of humor, absurdity, and philosophical depth make it a standout in the Coen brothers' repertoire. The characters are memorable, the dialogue is witty, and the overall experience is unforgettable.

Rating: 9/10.

review_title: Personal Opinions Are Laid To Rest
review_detailed_main: "The Dude abides", and rightfully so. With their greatest piece of work yet, the Coen Brothers have created a masterpiece with "The Big Lebowski". Whether consciously or subconsciously the Coen's have painted the most life like picture of Hollywood that has ever been seen by the naked eye. Raw, honest, and most of all hilarious "The Big Lebowski" tells the story of three good friends who's lives revolve around bowling. Even when one of them, "The Dude" (Jeff Bridges), gets caught up in a case of mistaken identity they still focus on the bowling league. This isn't all folks, HA! Anyone with half a brain will laugh at this movie, although anyone with the other half still in tact will surely see that even from Sam Elliot's opening monologue this entire film spoofs the hollywood process. Regardless of whether you recognize this or not, personal opinions are laid to rest with this film. It has been said that every individual has an individual personality but along with the dawn of this beautiful new Coen Brothers film is also the realization that there is not one person on this green old earth that can make it through "The Big Lebowski" without laughing. It is packed so tight with jokes that it'll make your grandadie's constipation look like a piece of cake. If you don't like this film or rate it anywhere below a 7 that is fine, for at that point of clicking the "vote" button with 7 or below you shall finally find that you are indeed retarded. Proceed to the doctor's immediately for treatment, because if you rate this film 7 or below you are in need of medical attention. Personal opinions are laid to rest!

Those who have said that this is not a good movie didn't understand one bit of it, or tried to understand too much. This is an 'awesome' movie (,man) and it is unique in the way it brings bottom-of-the-belly laughing (or: the instinctive, natural type of laughter if you'd like) to a modern genre that's hard to associate with humor. One of the best I've ever seen besides Jim Jarmusch's Down by Law. Not that it's comparable, but...

In short, it's a very funny, yet intellectual look at life through the eyes of the bozos that we all are. Go see it!

I remember watching this movie for the first time and found it to be pretty good. The second time I watched it I was in fits of laughter. By the third time I was hysterical! This movie has so many in-jokes and funny scenes you simply will not catch them all in one sitting.

The story itself as a crime movie is absolutely brilliant. Never have I seen so many characters involved in one plot so well, and all because of a rug! (well, partially). Jeff Bridges, John Goodman, and Steve Buscemi give a magnificent performance, and their friendship on screen as a group of guys doing nothing but bowl and drink beer is one to admire. "The Dude" is probably one of the coolest characters ever created, but to be fair, everyones character has been remarkably developed.

This movie is hilarious and if you are looking for something "chilled" and funny then this is it dude!

Rating -5 out of 5-

So far I've thoroughly enjoyed all the Coen Bros. Films I've seen. Until now. A misfit bunch of characters trying so hard to be larger than life succeeded only in making me cringe. So much so that I had a headache afterwards. Decent enough plotline and story, but really, the acting was OTT. And, sorry, Julianne Moore, that accent was more Dick van Dyke than Mary Poppins.

So, to summarise: meh!

This fabulous comedy by the Coen-brothers only keeps getting better and better the more times you see it. Bridges is perfectly cast as 'The Dude', the easy-going, laid-back kind of guy who spends his time bowling, smoking weed and listening to his Creedance-tapes. Goodman as Vietnam-veteran Walter who sees a conspiracy in almost everything and doesn't want to be bothered on "his" Jewish holidays comes up with another great performance as well as Buscemi, Moore, Seymour Hoffman and Turturro (in a very small, but entertaining role as bowling-king Jesus). And then there is Elliott as The Stranger who says he hasn't heard of a story as stupifying as this one. I couldn't agree more. Great writing, superb acting and a terrifying marmot!!!

This film shines like a great big ball of burning gas in the sky, providing all who live beneath its great shining beauty with warmth and light and happiness. It truly is one of the most amazingly brilliant masterpieces ever made, packed with visual and verbal invention, skill and class. Every second, every frame is simply magical, from the grimy milky toilet of the opening scene through all those wonderfully colourful, crazy dream sequences to the final pan of the camera away from our heroes, a riot of colour, imagery and beauty. The story is a wonderfully rambling, sprawling tale based loosely on Raymond Chandler and old Bogey movies, packed with Chandler staples and nods to great classic film noir, the characters are all brilliantly conceived, written and played. Bridges and Goodman make a truly classic odd-buddy combination, Buscemi and Turturro play wonderful minor comic figures wonderfully, Julianna Moore, Philip Seymour Hoffman, David Thewlis, the list of great actors playing out of their skins goes on and on. The music is perfect, Sam Eliot's narration is awe-inspiring (who else could possibly have played that part?), but above all it is the visual splendour of every scene which makes this film really stand out. What the Coens have created here will last forever as one of the very last great cinematic achievements of the Twentieth century, and sets a standard towards which all future filmmakers will have to stretch themselves to the utmost to reach. A truly flawless film which leaves the viewer with a lasting sense of pleasure and satisfaction and even manages to improve with each successive viewing, The Big Lebowski deserves every possible award and recognition available, and should be seen by every sensible person on the planet as often as possible. Only through this can true world peace and prosperity be achieved.

review_title: This film is truly an under-rated gem! A classic!
review_detailed_main:
As I look over the other comments for the Coen Brothers' film, _The Big Lebowski_, I see that I am not alone in my appreciation. When I first saw this film in the theater, it was a bit of a let-down, coming on the heels of the brilliant _Fargo_ (one of the greatest American films of the last 20 years, and that's no understatement). But when I first rented it on home video, I was sucked in by the charm and the atmosphere of the film.

It has such a laid-back, easygoing style that I can see how it might not appeal to those looking for nonstop action. But if you're willing to surrender to the peculiar charms of this film, you too might begin to see it for the work of genius it is. I've since purchased the film on video and have watched it several more times--it really is a film that grows on you and it is hilarious to boot.

John Goodman has never been better than in the role of the insufferable Walter, who knows everything and will never admit he's wrong, even when he clearly is. But he's a true friend to the Dude, played by Jeff Bridges, and Donny, played by Steve Buscemi. The three of them are bowling buddies, and in the course of preparing for the big tournament, they get pulled into a weird little mixup involving a carpet, a wayward wife, and the Big Lebowski, who just happens to have the same name as Bridge's character.

I've seen this described elsewhere as a sort of anti-mystery and that's one way of enjoying it. Imagine Jeff Bridges as a sort of stoned, clueless Philip Marlowe, stumbling through his investigation. The comedy though is just so relaxed and unforced, unlike that in the Coens' _Raising Arizona_, a film I've never been able to watch. The acting in this film is amazing, with a cast of independent film allstars.

The more I think about it, the more I wonder if this film might not be just that much better than _Fargo_. If not, it's a very close second. If you rent the film and it doesn't appeal to you at first, give it a chance--you might find that it grows on you, too.

review_title: Big Lebowski unfairly treated by many
review_detailed_main: I have seen this fine film numerous times, and still find it to be a hilarious piece of cinema. However, many of my friends and associates continue to insist that the Big Lebowski is a waste of time. Most of these people have not even bothered to watch the movie a second time. It is not until seeing it again that the movie does not make sense. I urge anyone who has seen this movie once, to rent it, and watch it again, it will be worth it. And if you haven't seen it, rent it, and watch it twice... If anyone has met resistance when preaching the creamy goodness of the Big Lebowski, please contact me.

This might not be the best movie you have ever seen. The first time you see it, you probably will not love it, but after you see it a couple of times and start thinking back on it, it becomes a favorite. The characters really jump out at you, even the non-main ones.

This movie is so fun to watch. The Coen brothers are magicians with dialogue and characters. I love their style of film-making and writing. This film, like many of their films, is very character-driven. A great soundtrack and some great cinematography round out this effort. This film gets quoted by my friends and I as much as any film there is. If you get a chance, go rent this Coen Classic right now, as a matter of fact, get them all.

9/10

review_title: Plot hits a brick wall halfway through and doesn't recover
